citation.article-title: Rhabdothermus arcticus gen. nov., sp. nov., a member of the family Thermaceae isolated from a hydrothermal vent chimney in the Soria Moria vent field on the Arctic Mid-Ocean Ridge
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Rhabdothermus arcticus sp. nov.
Rhabdothermus arcticus (arc′ti.cus. L. masc. adj. arcticus northern, Arctic, the place of origin of the type strain).
Displays the following properties in addition to those given in the genus description.
Grows optimally at 65 °C, at pH 7.3 and in 2.5–3.5 % (w/v) NaCl.
Obligately heterotrophic, growing on complex organic substrates like yeast extract, Casamino acids, tryptone and peptone.
Pyruvate, acetate, butyrate, rhamnose, sucrose and maltodextrin are used as complementary substrates.
The major fatty acids present are iso-C17 : 0, iso-C15 : 0 and iso-C17 : 1ω9c.
Polar lipids comprise two unidentified phospholipids and eight unidentified glycolipids.

The type strain, 2M70-1T ( = JCM 15963T = DSM 22268T), was isolated from the wall of an active white smoker chimney (270 °C) located ~700 m below sea-level in the Soria Moria vent field at 71 °N in the Norwegian–Greenland Sea.
The DNA G+C content of the type strain is 68 mol% (Tm).
